I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help Armenia establish its 
National Spatial Data Infrastructure (NSDI) through research and development and capacity 
building. The TA will develop foundational national geospatial data standards and a national 
integrated multifunctional geoportal to empower effective land management in Armenia, thus 
enabling economic activities while also enhancing its e-government capacity, as per goals in the 
Programme of the Government of the Republic of Armenia.1 
 
2.  The TA, requested by the government through its Cadastre Committee, is in the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) country operation business plan for Armenia, 2021–2023.2 The TA is 
consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy for Armenia, 2019–2023 and will enable efforts 
to foster diversified growth and widen inclusiveness through three pillars: priority infrastructure 
investments, targeted service delivery improvements, and greater regional cooperation and 
integration.3 The TA aligns with Sustainable Development Goals 11 (make cities and human 
settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable) and 13 (strengthen resilience and adaptive 
capacity to climate-related hazards and disasters triggered by natural hazards). The project will 
support five out of seven of ADB Strategy 2030’s operational priorities: (i) addressing remaining 
poverty and reducing inequalities, (ii) accelerating progress in gender equality, (iii) tackling climate 
change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability, (iv) 
strengthening governance and institutional capacity, and (v) making cities more livable.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Armenia is a landlocked country with an area of about 30,000 square kilometers in the 
South Caucasus. In mid-2018, ADB classified Armenia as Group C country. In 2020, Armenia 
had a population of about 3 million and gross domestic product per capita of $4,269.5 
 
4.  Despite its relatively small size and its upper middle income country status, Armenia lacks 
a unified or digitized system that collects and maintains spatial data information of its territory and 
interlinks with sectoral cadastres.6 This results in mismatched information causing erroneous and 
non-transparent information about the designation, usage, and ownership of land. Since the shift 
from a planned economy to a market-based economy, Armenia has struggled with the cadastral 
and titling system, primarily because of resource constraints and a lack of experience in cadastral 
issues.

5.   As of January 2021, Armenia’s land parcels and other thematic maps are encoded in 
various standards and require harmonization. Armenia needs to establish an entire national 
spatial data management system, including the foundational technical guidelines for encoding 
spatial data, with NSDI standards to encapsulate geospatial data development, production, 
management, access, sharing, visualization, and analysis. 
 
6.  The Cadastre Committee is the official body, directly under the central government, tasked 
with (i) developing and implementing real estate market policy (including taxes); (ii) the state 
registration of property rights in order to recognize and guarantee rights and encumbrances to 
the property; and (iii) establishing an information system on property, providing information, and 
managing and supervising the system’s activity. The Cadastre Committee comprises a head 
office in Yerevan and a network of 40 service offices in different communities of Armenia. In 
coordination with the Urban Development Committee, the Cadastre Committee is mandated by 
law to elaborate land policy and principles of land resources management. This mandate is 
particularly important for planning any strategic investment in territorial development and urban 
infrastructure provision, and clearly needs to rely on updated and integrated digital maps. 
 
7.  Other state agencies responsible for maintaining field or thematic cadastres of objects, 
property, and resources operate independently, often duplicating data and complicating the 
process  of  providing  information  to  stakeholders.7 Unharmonized  data  stored  in  various 
databases challenges interagency collaboration, resulting in increases in transaction costs and 
delays  in  implementing  investment  programs.  Outdated  cadastral  maps  hamper  effective 
evaluation and monitoring of disasters and land degradation induced by natural hazards (Armenia 
is prone to seismic activity) and climate change, as well as efforts to recover from or adapt to 
them through vulnerability mapping. The integrated cadastre will eventually interlink with the 
following sectoral and thematic cadastres: national water resources, national forests, special 
protected natural areas, solid waste, flora, historical and cultural monuments, national urban 
cadastre, and fauna. Responsible parties will continuously update the sectoral cadastres and their 
usage will help increase investments in Armenia, effective use of agricultural lands, and tourism 
development, among other benefits.  
 
8.  Inaccurate  cadastral  data  hampers  infrastructure  project  implementation;  tripartite 
portfolio review meetings of ADB-financed projects have identified it as a significant project 
implementation issue since 2017. Incorrect information results in poor design and planning, 
making it difficult to identify the best alternatives with minimized resettlement impact. The time-
consuming  process  of  cadastral  data  correction  for  land  acquisition,  along  with  project 
realignment because of unrecorded cadastral layers, also slows implementation of infrastructure

the integrated cadastre governance system includes the following public administration bodies: (i) State Cadastre 
Committee, developer-responsible executor; (ii) Ministry of Environment; (iii) Ministry of Territorial Administration and 
Infrastructure; (iv) Ministry of Culture; and (v) Urban Development Committee. The Ministry of Transport and 
Infrastructure is involved as an authorized body in connection with the implementation of cadastral functions of local 
communities.  Other  government  agencies  maintaining  thematic  cadastres  are:  (i)  Ministry  of  Environment, 
responsible for maintaining the (a) Forest Cadastre, (b) Water Resources State Cadastre, (c) Specially Protected

Ministry of Territorial Administration and Infrastructure, responsible for maintaining the Extractable Resources State 
Cadastre; (iii) Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sport, responsible for maintaining the Protection and Use 
of Immovable Historical and Cultural Monuments and Historical Circle State Cadastre; (iv) State Urban Committee, 
responsible for maintaining the Urban Development State Cadastre; and (v) Ministry of Economy, responsible for 
maintaining the Agricultural Lands State Cadastre. These agencies are informed about the TA and are willing to 
coordinate for the integration of a unified cadastre, which will benefit their respective mandates.

projects. The economic restrictions caused by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) have also 
highlighted the need and importance of e-government tools to ensure uninterrupted operations of 
public services during lockdown and post-lockdown periods. For example, the issuance of 
certificates for land ownership for applying for mortgages was suspended for months, effectively 
freezing the real estate market with consequences for the most vulnerable segments of the 
population. 
 
9.  Lack of an integrated platform for easy and remote access to transparent and accurate 
land information creates inefficiencies in the real estate market and the national land use’s policy-
making. The law requires that land use schemes, zoning plans, and spatial planning documents 
be open. They are, however, either not available at all or are available in formats that are not 
easily accessible for citizens. As a result, for years, the Cadastre Committee provided this 
information to citizens upon request, only as prescribed by law. Thus, the heads of communities 
could arbitrarily dispose land slots without public oversight. A digital cadastre would substantially 
reduce corruption risks while saving people time and money. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: effective land management empowered.8 The 
TA will have the following outcome: e-governance systems established for land-use planning and 
management and public services delivery.9 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output 1: National geospatial data standards developed. Geospatial data standards 
are the basis for NSDI development. The TA will study best international practices, including those 
that have successfully integrated gender in their geographic information system, to develop at 
least 10 geospatial data standards to direct and regulate spatial data collection and sharing. 
Improving the regulatory framework will enhance the initiative’s effectiveness and sustainability 
by laying a solid foundation on which to build and guide land development and management 
activities. Based on global best practices and eventually on the choice of the most suitable 
standards  in  the  Armenian  context  (i.e.,  conforming  with  acting  laws  and  the  Armenian 
Constitution and adopting local legal-normative requirements), the TA will develop the terms of 
reference for establishing an integrated multifunctional national geoportal (output 2). 
 
12.  Output  2:  National  geoportal  for  spatial  data  management  developed  and 
government capacity strengthened. The TA will help develop a national geographic information 
system platform which can host, integrate, and manage databases with layers such as: (i) 
addresses, (ii) cadastral parcels, (iii) geographical grid systems, (iv) geographical names, (v) 
coordinate reference systems, (vi) elevation, and (vii) transport networks. The TA will develop 
data models to properly house records on property ownerships, buildings, parcels, land raster 
and vector data, and associated metadata.10 Based on the standards developed, the Cadastre 
Committee will standardize existing data and basic cartographic layers and migrate them into the

cooperation, and interoperability of thematic databases. Integration of gender, e.g., use of sex-
disaggregated data in land ownership, in the sectoral and integrated cadastres will enable the 
government to do gender-responsive development planning. 
 
13.  Output 3: Standardized custom cartographic layers developed and migrated into 
the geoportal for one administrative division of Armenia. Custom layers imply cadastres of 
objects, properties, and resources, as well as geospatial information necessary for their effective 
management. The output is associated with: (i) creation of basic cartographic layers with the 
relevant  standards  and  integration  into  the  geoportal,  and  (ii)  testing  of  the  integrated 
standardized custom cartographic layers into the geoportal for one of the administrative divisions 
of Armenia (to be selected at a later stage to ensure coordination with ADB urban sector 
operations). 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,300,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund (EAKPF); and (ii) 
$800,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the High-Level Technology (HLT) Fund, both to be 
administered by ADB.12 The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of hardware infrastructure to host and run the geoportal, 
counterpart staff, office accommodation, and other in-kind contributions.13 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA. The Cadastre Committee will be the executing agency. The 
Centre for Geomatics under the Cadastre Committee will be the implementing agency. The 
Armenia Resident Mission and the Urban Development and Water Division of ADB’s Central and 
West Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants. Two firms will be engaged 
to implement output 1 and outputs 2–3 individually. The consultants will procure goods for TA 
implementation and organize roundtables with key stakeholders, also to serve as on-the-job 
training, and capacity building workshops following ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time).
